etymologies: Old English wyrm (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Latin vermis ‘worm’ and Greek rhomox ‘woodworm’

definitions: any of a number of creeping or burrowing invertebrate animals with long, slender soft bodies and no limbs.

notes.text: Phyla Annelida (segmented worms), Nematoda (roundworms), and Platyhelminthes (flatworms), and up to twelve minor phyla

shortDefinitions: invertebrate animal with long, slender soft body

examples.text: she ate so much so often that I thought she had worms

definitions: used in names of long, slender insect larvae, especially those in fruit or wood, e.g. army worm, woodworm.
shortDefinitions: used in names of long slender insect larvae

definitions: used in names of other animals that resemble worms in some way, e.g. slow-worm, shipworm.
shortDefinitions: used in names of other animals that resemble worms

definitions: a maggot supposed to eat buried corpses
shortDefinitions: maggot regarded as eating corpses buried in ground

definitions: a dragon or other mythical snake-like reptile.
a weak or despicable person (used as a general term of contempt)

examples.text: it was unbearable that such a worm could be so successful

definitions: the threaded cylinder in a worm gear.
the coiled pipe of a still in which the vapor is cooled and condensed.
shortDefinitions: coiled pipe of still in which vapour is cooled and condensed

definitions: a self-replicating program able to propagate itself across a network, typically having a detrimental effect.
shortDefinitions: self-replicating program able to propagate itself across network

definitions: move with difficulty by crawling or wriggling

examples.text: I wormed my way along the roadside ditch

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: move with difficulty by crawling or wriggling

definitions: move (something) into a confined space by wriggling it

examples.text: I wormed my right hand between my body and the earth

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: move something into confined space by wriggling it

examples.text: the educated dealers may later worm their way into stockbroking

definitions: obtain information from (someone) by cunning persistence

examples.text: I did manage to worm a few details out of him

shortDefinitions: obtain information from someone by cunning persistence

definitions: treat (an animal) with a preparation designed to expel parasitic worms

examples.text: I wormed her over a course of three weeks

shortDefinitions: treat animal with preparation designed to expel parasitic worms

definitions: make (a rope) smooth by winding small cordage between the strands.
shortDefinitions: make rope smooth by winding thread between strands
